item.title: Oslo tips
item.description:
A collection of tips for people visiting Oslo. 1

Drinks

  • Andre til Høyre
  • Himkok
  • Torggata Botaniske
  • Eff Eff Oyster and Wine Bar

Beers

  • Crowbar
  • Brygg
  • Schouskjelleren Mikrobryggeri
  • The Dubliner
  • St. Pauli Biergarten

Night out

  • Play shuffleboard at Kulturhuset
  • Elsker
  • Silly singing at Syng Grunerløkka
  • Check what music plays at Blå. Sundays at Blå are a classic.
  • Justisen
  • Fancy places at Solli
  • Torggata bad

Coffee

  • Talormade Bispevika (donuts!)
  • Tim Wendelboe (Award winning)
  • Neongrut
  • Dapper
  • Supreme Roastwork
  • Oslo raw (cakes)
  • Anne på Landet - Frognerparken
  • Fuglen
  • Bonita Cafe & Brunch

Brunch

item.title: Colombia tips
item.description:
A collection of tips for people visiting Colombia. 1

Bogota

  • Climb up to Montserrate and admire the gloomy landscape of this massive urban jungle.
  • City centre (La Candelaria): Discover where everything began at the capital of the old Nueva Granada Kingdom. During your walk go to Plaza Bolivar, Chorro de quevedo, Museo del Oro and la Puerta Falsa for the best ajiaco in town.
  • Gold Museum: the Museo del Oro is one of its kind, admire all the gold pieces will help you to understand the legend of El Dorado as well the aboriginal prehispanic cultured such as the Muisca, Tayrona or Pijao.
  • Take a graffiti tour: its worth it due to all the artistic painting all around the city.
  • Zona G: neighbourhood where you will find English houses following the Tudor style in the Chapinero area.
  • Leo Cocina y Cava: A michelin restaurant from the best Latin American chef Leonor Espinoza.
  • Enjoy nightlife like a Rolo (bogotano): there is no place like Bogota to party like Andres Carne de Res (the one in Chia is better than the one in Bogotá centre).
  • Check out Theatrón (nightclub).
  • And also, for book lovers, Merlin is a must go.

Near Bogota:

item.title: Estimation fact sheet
item.description:
Populations (city)

  • Tokyo: 37m
  • Dehli: 29m
  • Shanghai: 26m
  • Sao Paulo: 22m
  • Istambul: 16m
  • London: 9m
  • Paris: 9m
  • Barcelona: 1.6m

Populations (country)

  • China: 1.44b
  • India: 1.38b
  • USA: 331m
  • Indonesia: 274m
  • Germany: 84m
  • UK: 67m
  • Spain: 47m

Timeframes

  • Big Bang: 13.8b
  • Earth: 4.5b
  • Prokaryotes: 3.7b
  • Australopithecus: 5m
  • Homo Habilis: 2m
  • Neanderthal: 100k
  • Human: 80k
  • Civilisation: 6k

Electricity (consumption)

  • Iphone charge (1 charge): 6Wh
  • Desktop computer (hour): 200Wh
  • Apartment in Oslo (month): 100kWh to 980kWh
  • Apartment in Oslo (year): 6000kWh

Companies (Revenue / Margin / # of employees / valuation)

  • Apple: 367 billion / 25% / 154,000 / 3 trillion
  • Shell / 261 billion / 7% / 86,000 / 212 million
  • Tesla / 53 billion / 27% / 10,000 / 828 billion
  • Affirm / 0.870 billion / -77% / 2,071 / 5 billion
  • Duolingo / 0.24 billion / -23% / 500 / 2.5 billion
  • Google / 256 billion / 26% / 150k / 1.4 trillion
  • Otovo / 60 million / ?% / ? / ?

General sense of product / tech metrics

  • Amazon S3 Standard cost: $0.023 / GB / month
  • Average file size for a 90-min 720p movie: roughly 3.5GB
  • Average file size for a smartphone camera picture: roughly 3-5 MB
  • Average CTR for a search ad: 1.91%
  • Average landing page conversion rate: 2.35%
  • Average WiFi bandwidth: ~10Mbps
  • Cost of iPhone 12 Pro: $999
  • Cost of Google Pixel 5: $699

General sense of user populations

  • Netflix (Q2 2021): 209 million subscribers
  • Google G Suite (March 2020): 2 billion+ monthly active users
  • Uber (Jun 2021): ~1 million drivers in the US
  • Twitter (Q1 2018): 192 million daily active users

General sense of demographics

  • EU population per age (0-20, 20-40, 40-60, 60-80): 25%
  • EU population per class (lower-middle-upper): 20%-70%-10%
  • Number of households: population / population per household

General sense of heights

  • Planes: 8k-11k meters
  • Everest: 8849 m
  • Burj Khalifa: 828m
  • Empire State Building: 381m
  • Torre Maphre: 154m
  • Torre de Collserola: 288m

item.title: Compiled Life Advice from Hacker News
item.description:
I decided to read a bunch of “life advice” threads from hacker news which I summarized below:

  • Do regular blood tests / healthchecks
  • Eat less
  • Maintenaince is harder than building things up - cultivate a habit of exercising early since this will only become - harder
  • Take good care of you teeth
  • Some fun activities include lifting, cyclying, surf, dancing…
  • Do stretch / pick up yoga
  • Fight the urge of becoming complacent - learn and try things personally and professionally
  • Set strict workhours - stress will greatly impact you mental and physical health, it is rarely worth it
  • Have clear goals for yourself every month, year and decade
  • Minimize distractions - it is hard to overstate how important this is an how bad most people are at it
  • Conciously work to regret more things
  • Get good sleep - at least 8 hours
  • Find a good therapist
  • Avoid attaching your identity to people, their idea of who you are, youre job, or you posessions
  • Be a “bro” not a “bob” at work - get excited about things, don’t complain and do talk to the younger / newer people
  • Do medidate
  • Do exercise regularly - it will pay huge dividends later in life
  • Remember that at 30 you can still drop everything and go hike the Appalachian trail, at 40 that might not be possible - nor sound appealing
  • Love your boyfriend/girlfriend as much as you did when you where a teenager
  • Be a doer, not a talker
  • Wear earplugs at concerts
  • Realize how much incentives matter - everything is driven by “personal incentives” more so that “business incentives” - and these two aren’t usually aligned
  • Make the most out of your time with your parents
  • Marry someone “above your station” emotionally
  • Find the right set of people to surround yourself with and mantain these relationships
  • Keep track of your friends (and their contact details) and reach out to them often
  • Have parties
  • Dress nicely, not to impress but to not look like a slob
  • Pick one activity and commit to it for the next decade to get as good as you can
  • Get a good mouse and keyboard
  • Decide early whether you want kids

item.title: Markdown Syntax Guide
item.description: This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.
